headline: Microsoft’s (NASDAQ:MSFT) Q4 CY2025 Sales Top Estimates
summary: Technology giant Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) reported revenue ahead of Wall Streets expectations in Q4 CY2025, with sales up 16.7% year on year to $81.27 billion. Its GAAP profit of $5.16 per share was 34.1% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Microsoft's rising spending, slight cloud beat fan AI payoff worries
summary: Microsoft only edged past estimates for quarterly revenue in its crucial cloud-computing business on Wednesday and ramped up spending on artificial intelligence, disappointing investors looking for ​better returns amid intense competition.  The company also reported that ‌the contracted backlog in its cloud business more than doubled to $625 billion, which was more than the $523 billion rival Oracle posted ‌in December.  But roughly 45% of Microsoft's backlog was driven by OpenAI alone, underscoring its reliance on the money-losing startup that has pledged around $1.4 trillion in overall AI expenditure with little details on how it plans to fund the spending.

raw.headline: Microsoft's rising spending, slight cloud beat fan AI payoff worries
raw.summary: Microsoft only edged past estimates for quarterly revenue in its crucial cloud-computing business on Wednesday and ramped up spending on artificial intelligence, disappointing investors looking for ​better returns amid intense competition.  The company also reported that ‌the contracted backlog in its cloud business more than doubled to $625 billion, which was more than the $523 billion rival Oracle posted ‌in December.  But roughly 45% of Microsoft's backlog was driven by OpenAI alone, underscoring its reliance on the money-losing startup that has pledged around $1.4 trillion in overall AI expenditure with little details on how it plans to fund the spending.

headline: Layoffs are piling up, heightening worker anxiety. Here are some of the biggest job cuts recently
summary: As layoffs pile up, workers are feeling increasingly anxious about the job market.  Hiring has stagnated overall — with the country adding a meager 50,000 jobs last month, down from a revised figure of 56,000 in November.  Employers have initiated layoffs across sectors — with many pointing to rising operational costs that span from President Donald Trump’s barrage of new tariffs, stubborn inflation and shifts in spending from consumers, whose outlook on the U.S. economy recently plummeted to its lowest level since 2014.

headline: Amazon Sends Premature Layoff Email as 14,000-Cut Restructuring Lingers
summary: This article first appeared on GuruFocus.  Amazon.com Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) employees anticipating another round of job cuts were jolted late Tuesday after an internal email from senior vice president Colleen Aubrey surfaced earlier than intended, briefly scheduling a meeting titled Project Dawn.  The message, later canceled, referenced impacted colleagues across the US, Canada and Costa Rica, and pointed to a separate note from human resources chief Beth Galetti that does not appear to have been sent.

raw.headline: Amazon Sends Premature Layoff Email as 14,000-Cut Restructuring Lingers
raw.summary: This article first appeared on GuruFocus.  Amazon.com Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) employees anticipating another round of job cuts were jolted late Tuesday after an internal email from senior vice president Colleen Aubrey surfaced earlier than intended, briefly scheduling a meeting titled Project Dawn.  The message, later canceled, referenced impacted colleagues across the US, Canada and Costa Rica, and pointed to a separate note from human resources chief Beth Galetti that does not appear to have been sent.

headline: Amazon to Cut 16,000 Jobs. What’s Behind Its Largest Ever Corporate Layoffs.
summary: Amazon.com  said Wednesday it will cut 16,000 jobs as the online retailer completes its largest-ever corporate layoffs.  The latest cuts will bring Amazon’s total layoffs to roughly 30,000 after it said last October it would eliminate around 14,000 roles.  Put together, the announcements suggest Amazon is slashing nearly 10% of its corporate workforce.

Put together, the announcements suggest Amazon is slashing nearly 10% of its corporate workforce.

headline: Labor market has been adjusting to being in 'shock-prone world'
summary: Amazon (AMZN) plans to layoff an additional 16,000 corporate workers — now totaling 30,000 positions cut by the e-commerce giant since October 2025 — as part of the company's latest push to adopt AI and "[remove] bureaucracy" to increase efficiency.As earnings season kicks into full swing for Big Tech companies, Deutsche Bank chief global strategist Binky Chadha takes an extensive look at the performance of the US labor market coming out of the pandemic and President Trump's own "Liberation Day" tariff policies.Amazon is scheduled to report earnings next week on Thursday, February 5.To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Tech fuels stocks, Fed decision, Amazon layoffs: 3 Things

headline: Amazon cuts 16,000 jobs in second round of layoffs amid AI push
summary: STORY: Amazon announced Wednesday (January 28) it was cutting 16,000 jobs worldwide. It’s the company’s second major round of layoffs in three months. The tech giant is restructuring after pandemic-era over-hiring, and expanding the adoption of AI tools.Reuters reported last week that the layoffs are expected to affect workers in Amazon Web Services, retail, Prime Video and HR departments.Amazon slashed 14,000 white-collar jobs in late October.Executives stressed the need to get rid of excessive bureaucracy and lower the number of managers. But one senior leader said announcing broad reductions every few months is “not the plan”. The latest job cuts show how AI is changing corporate workforces. Significant improvements in AI assistants are helping enterprises with duties from admin tasks to complex coding with speed and precision. The 30,000 job cuts represent a small portion of Amazon's almost 1.6 million employees - but nearly 10% of its corporate workforce. The majority of Amazon's workers are in fulfillment centers and warehouses.But the firm's also invested in robotics in these departments to speed up packaging and deliveries, reducing the reliance on human labor.

raw.headline: Amazon cuts 16,000 jobs in second round of layoffs amid AI push
raw.summary: STORY: Amazon announced Wednesday (January 28) it was cutting 16,000 jobs worldwide. It’s the company’s second major round of layoffs in three months. The tech giant is restructuring after pandemic-era over-hiring, and expanding the adoption of AI tools.Reuters reported last week that the layoffs are expected to affect workers in Amazon Web Services, retail, Prime Video and HR departments.Amazon slashed 14,000 white-collar jobs in late October.Executives stressed the need to get rid of excessive bureaucracy and lower the number of managers. But one senior leader said announcing broad reductions every few months is “not the plan”. The latest job cuts show how AI is changing corporate workforces. Significant improvements in AI assistants are helping enterprises with duties from admin tasks to complex coding with speed and precision. The 30,000 job cuts represent a small portion of Amazon's almost 1.6 million employees - but nearly 10% of its corporate workforce. The majority of Amazon's workers are in fulfillment centers and warehouses.But the firm's also invested in robotics in these departments to speed up packaging and deliveries, reducing the reliance on human labor.

headline: Amazon to Cut 16,000 Corporate Positions to Trim Bureaucracy
summary: The tech firm will offer US-based employees 90 days to search for a new role internally, as well as severance and other transition support, Beth Galetti, Amazon’s senior vice president of people experience and technology said Wednesday in a blog post.  Companies across industries have been trimming management layers in the name of becoming leaner and more productive.  Just as Amazon was announcing its own layoffs, the chip-making machine giant ASML Holding NV said it’s eliminating 1,700 positions largely targeting managerial roles.

raw.headline: Amazon to Cut 16,000 Corporate Positions to Trim Bureaucracy

Companies across industries have been trimming management layers in the name of becoming leaner and more productive.  Just as Amazon was announcing its own layoffs, the chip-making machine giant ASML Holding NV said it’s eliminating 1,700 positions largely targeting managerial roles.

headline: Amazon to Cut 16,000 Jobs in Its Largest-Ever Corporate Layoffs
summary: Amazon.com  said Wednesday it will cut 16,000 jobs as the online retailer completes its largest-ever corporate layoffs.  The latest cuts will bring Amazon’s total layoffs to roughly 30,000 after it said last October it would eliminate around 14,000 roles.  Put together, the announcements suggest Amazon is slashing nearly 10% of its corporate workforce.

Although 30,000 represents a ​small portion of Amazon's 1.58 million employees, who are mostly in fulfillment centers and warehouses, it ‌is nearly 10% of its corporate workforce.  Reuters first reported last week that Amazon was planning a second round of job cuts as part of ‌the broader goal.

headline: UPS Q4 Deep Dive: Automation, Network Reconfiguration, and Amazon Glide Down Shape Outlook
summary: Parcel delivery company UPS (NYSE:UPS) reported Q4 CY2025 results topping the market’s revenue expectations, but sales fell by 3.2% year on year to $24.48 billion. The company’s full-year revenue guidance of $89.7 billion at the midpoint came in 2% above analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $2.38 per share was 8.1% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Amazon bungles Wednesday layoff plan with misfired internal email
summary: Amazon on Tuesday appeared to have prematurely alerted Amazon Web Services cloud-computing employees to layoffs planned ​for Wednesday morning by sending a commiseration email and team-wide meeting ‌invitation hours early.  Reuters reported on Friday that Amazon intended to lay off thousands of corporate employees starting ‌this week.  The email sent on Tuesday signed by Colleen Aubrey, senior vice president of applied AI solutions at AWS, wrongly said that impacted employees in ⁠the U.S., Canada and Costa ‌Rica had already been informed they lost their jobs.

Reuters reported on Friday that Amazon intended to lay off thousands of corporate employees starting ‌this week.  The email sent on Tuesday signed by Colleen Aubrey, senior vice president of applied AI solutions at AWS, wrongly said that impacted employees in ⁠the U.S., Canada and Costa ‌Rica had already been informed they lost their jobs.
